messageBody:
The server and client should probably be tested separatly.

One school of thought is that that you should abstract out the transport level
code into implementations of an interface you define, letting your provide
simple mock implementations to test against. This allows you to test the
logic of your code without actually using the network at anypoint, giving you
a lot of fine control over what happens when. Plus it encourages you to
factor out the transport level stuff which is a Good Thing (tm) anyway.

The approach I took last time I tried (before I'd got my head around the above
idea, being a JUnit novice at the time myself) was to consider the unit
testing as testing the public interface of the class, with the network calls
being part of that interface. To aid this kind of testing I wrote a simple
NetworkTester class that enabled simple send/expect conversations to be
carried out from either a server, or clients perspective.
The advantage of this is that you often expose some of the subtle networking
related problems that you might not see until production or (hopefully)
stress testing. Whether it counts as unit testing or not is maybe debatable.

Hope this makes some kinda sense.
Shez
